newsitem.title: UK: NWE fuel oil eyes French strike, Russian supplies.
newsitem.headline: NWE fuel oil eyes French strike, Russian supplies.

text.p: NWE fuel oil was steady to firmer on Tuesday gaining support from crude's recent rises.
Dealers were keeping a wary eye on Elf's labour dispute and Russian straight run avails.
Day six of the strike at Elf was causing concern, but there has been no large scale buying.

High sulphur barges moved up by $4 a tonne with trades at $125 and $126 fob ARA. Dealers said a growing shortage of product has help boost prices which settled in this range around midday. Moderate to fair bunker demand of 10-15,000 tonnes was also giving some support.

The high sulphur cracked cargo market was now looking more comfortable above $120 cif NWE with a definite tightness of supplies. But, demand was not especially visible and a number of end-users claim to have enough material for much of December.
The good availability of Russian straight run continues as does the the uncertainty as to when or indeed whether an export tariff will be applied. E-4 appear to be plentifully offered.

The low sulphur cracked cargo market was steady around $133 fob NWE with a second half 45-50,000 tonne cargo looking for $135 fob. A smaller 25,000 tonne cargo was no longer on the market and some dealers believe it is destined for the Med.
